raw_text:
Scotland 18-10 Italy
 
 Six Chris Paterson penalties gave Scotland victory in a dour but clinical encounter against Italy at Murrayfield.
 
 Coach Matt Williams' side were outmuscled and outplayed in a tense first half but led 6-3 at the break. Paterson slotted four more second-half penalties and Scotland were denied a try when wing Sean Lamont's touchdown was ruled out for a forward pass. A late Andrea Masi try was small consolation for Italy, chasing their first away win in the Six Nations. Scotland came out on top of the early exchanges and took a quick 3-0 lead through the boot of full-back Paterson. But the more powerful Azzurri pack eventually rumbled into life.
 
 A series of drives into Scottish territory set up a penalty attempt, missed by full-back Roland De Marigny, and a wayward drop-goal effort from Luciano Orquera. Scotland defended the initial thrusts but on 20 minutes Italy, after coming up yards short of the line, equalised through a De Marigny penalty. Italy were offered another penalty when Scottish flanker Simon Taylor was offside but the left-footed De Marigny pushed his kick wide. Scotland finally made the most of a rare foray into the Italian half and snatched three points from Paterson when an Italian forward handled the ball in a ruck.
 
 As the half wore on, both sides squandered promising spells of momentum with sloppy penalties, and the period fizzled out with Scotland numerically, if not psychologically, on top. Italy's De Marigny narrowly missed a chance to level the scores again shortly after the break but his long-range kick shaved the right upright. And Scotland capitalised with a third Paterson penalty on 50 minutes. Williams' side seemed to have found a spark from somewhere and, after a couple of probing attacks, Paterson was able to slot another three points to widen the gap.
 
 With the pendulum of possession swinging towards Scotland, Lamont thought he had wriggled over in the left corner after 65 minutes but play was recalled for a marginal forward pass from Paterson. Another Paterson penalty on 70 minutes kept the pressure on the wilting visitors. But John Kirwan's men had the last laugh when Gordon Ross' attempted clearance was charged down and Masi pounced for the try, converted by De Marigny.
 
 : C Paterson; S Webster, A Craig, H Southwell, S Lamont; D Parks, C Cusiter; T Smith, G Bulloch (capt), G Kerr; S Grimes, S Murray; S Taylor, J Petrie, A Hogg.
 
 R Russell, B Douglas, N Hines, J Dunbar, M Blair, G Ross, B Hinshelwood.
 
 R de Marigny; Mirco Bergamasco, C Stoica, A Masi, L Nitoglia; L Orquera, A Troncon; A Lo Cicero, F Ongaro, M Castrogiovanni; S Dellape, M Bortolami (capt); A Persico, D Dal Maso, S Parisse.
 
 G Intoppa, S Perugini, CA del Fava, S Orlando, P Griffen, R Pedrazzi, KP Robertson.
llama3.2:1b:
Scotland won 18-10 against Italy in the Six Nations rugby match.

Italy led 6-3 at the end of the first half and Scotland responded with a try by Sean Lamont on 65 minutes. 

The game saw several penalty attempts denied to both sides, but ultimately Scotland capitalized with three Paterson penalties, including one on 70 minutes that sealed the win.

Scotland's Chris Paterson was instrumental in scoring the winning points, while Italy's Andrea Masi scored a consolation try after being denied a try himself by a forward pass.
llama3.2:3b: Scotland won 18-10 against Italy at Murrayfield in a dour match. Scotland's Chris Paterson scored six penalties to seal victory after Italy equalized through Roland De Marigny's penalty and Azzurri try from Andrea Masi. The game fizzled out with sloppy penalties, but Paterson's last kick kept pressure on Italy until their late consolation try.
gemma2:2b: Scotland won against Italy at Murrayfield with a final score of 18-10.  Six penalties by Chris Paterson were the difference in this dour and clinical match. A late try for Italy, scored by Andrea Masi, was not enough to overcome Scotland's advantage.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Scotland defeated Italy 3-0 in the Six Nations Rugby World Cup after scoring three points (Patterson, Cusiter and Lamont) in the first half. Paterson scored four penalties that contributed to Scotland's victory over Italy.

Key details:
1. Team: Scotland 
2. Match: Murrayfield 
3. Results:
   - Scotland 6-3 (first half)
   - Italy 6-3
4. Penalties:
   - Paterson (six) 
   - Lamont (four)
5. Breakdown of penalties:
   - Paterson scored four second-half penalties
   - Lamont had a penalty that was ruled out for a forward pass

Summary: Scotland defeated Italy in the Six Nations Rugby World Cup, winning 3-0 with six Chris Paterson penalties securing the victory.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Scotland beat Italy 18-10 in a close Six Nations encounter with Chris Paterson's six penalties securing victory at Murrayfield. Italy scored through Andrea Masi but were unable to convert their late try. Scotland took the lead early and held it until late into the second half before scoring three more points, while Italy struggled with poor execution and missed several penalty attempts.
qwen2.5:3b: Scotland won 18-10 against Italy at Murrayfield in a tight match. Chris Paterson scored six penalties, including three in the second half and another on 50 minutes to secure Scotland's lead. A late try by Andrea Masi for Italy could not compensate for this deficit. The Italian side had early chances but failed to capitalize, while Scotland's defense held firm despite being outplayed in the first half. Wales' Matt Williams' tactics were effective throughout, exploiting Italy's errors and poor decision-making.

Six Chris Paterson penalties gave Scotland victory in a dour but clinical encounter against Italy at Murrayfield.

Coach Matt Williams' side were outmuscled and outplayed in a tense first half but led 6-3 at the break. A late Andrea Masi try small consolation for Italy, chasing their first away win in the Six Nations.

A series of drives into Scottish territory set up a penalty attempt, missed by full-back Roland De Marigny, and a wayward drop-goal effort from Luciano Orquera. Scotland came out on top of the early exchanges and took a quick 3-0 lead through the boot of full-back Paterson.

But the more powerful Azzurri pack eventually rumbled into life. A rare foray into the Italian half and snatched three points from Paterson when an Italian forward handled the ball in a ruck.

Key Players: Chris Paterson led Scotland in an unflinching fight against Italy at Murrayfield. Paterson scored six crucial penalties to secure their win.

tinyllama:1.1b: As the first half of Scotland's victory over Italy in the Six Nations concluded, Paterson scored six penalties for his team, which led to a comfortable win against the Italians. Coach Matt Williams' side dominated both sides with their clinical play and tight defense, while Italy struggled to make any significant breakthroughs. In the second half, Italy tried to claw back into the match but were ultimately unable to score against Scotland's impressive defense. Despite a sluggish start, Scotland eventually claimed victory, with Paterson netting four more penalties for his team in the final quarter.

phi:2.7b: In a tense encounter at Murrayfield, Scotland defeated Italy by six points after receiving six Chris Paterson penalties in the first half. Despite being outmuscled and outplayed, coach Matt Williams' team took an early lead of 6-3, but Italy came back to even the scores with two missed penalty kicks. After another unsuccessful attempt from Italy, Paterson managed to convert his third penalty kick, giving Scotland a three-point lead. However, the momentum shifted towards Italy when they scored their first try in the game. The rest of the period was a battle between both teams, but after several opportunities, Paterson's fourth penalty kick secured another win for Scotland.
orca-mini:3b: Scotland defeated Italy 18-10 in a closely contested Six Nations match at Murrayfield. Chris Paterson scored six penalties for Scotland, including three in the second half, to help his side gain the upper hand. However, the Italian pack eventually rumbled into life and denied a try when wing Sean Lamont's touchdown was ruled out for a forward pass. The teams traded sloppy penalties, and the period fizzled out with Scotland numerically, if not psychologically, on top. Italy's Luciano Orquera narrowly missed a chance to level the scores again shortly after the break but Scotland capitalised with a third Paterson penalty on 50 minutes. John Kirwan's men had the last laugh when Gordon Ross' attempted clearance was charged down and Masi pounced for the try, converted by De Marigny.
hermes3:3b: Scotland beats Italy 18-10 in the Six Nations match at Murrayfield, thanks to Chris Paterson's four penalties.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Scotland won 18-10 against Italy in a Six Nations match at Murrayfield. Scotland's Chris Paterson scored six penalties, and Italy's only try came late in the game from Andrea Masi. The match saw both teams struggle with handling errors and missed opportunities. Scotland took an early lead and led 6-3 at halftime. Italy equalized through a penalty by Roland De Marigny but couldn't overcome Scotland's strong performance.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Scotland secured an 18-10 victory over Italy at Murrayfield, thanks to six penalties from Chris Paterson in a scrappy but effective performance. Despite being outplayed in the first half, Scotland led 6-3 at the break. Paterson added four more penalties in the second half, while Scotland was denied a try when Sean Lamont’s score was ruled out for a forward pass. Italy, seeking their first away win in the Six Nations, managed a late consolation try through Andrea Masi, converted by Roland De Marigny. Italy’s powerful pack initially put Scotland under pressure, but missed penalty attempts proved costly. Scotland capitalized on their opportunities, with Paterson’s accuracy proving decisive.
stablelm2:1.6b: Scotland defeated Italy 9-6 in a tense match at Murrayfield, with Chris Paterson scoring six penalties to secure the victory. Scotland took an early lead through Paterson's boot but Italy came back with a try from Roland De Marigny's penalty attempt. Both sides had opportunities to score during the second half, ultimately resulting in a 9-6 win for Scotland.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Scotland secured a 18-10 victory over Italy at Murrayfield, thanks to six penalty conversions by Chris Paterson. Despite being outmatched and outplayed in the first half, Scotland took a 6-3 lead into halftime. The Italian team, aiming for their first away win in the Six Nations, managed one try late in the game, scored by Andrea Masi. Key moments included a controversial denied Scottish try due to a forward pass and a series of Italian drives that threatened the Scottish defense. Paterson's accuracy with penalties, along with a successful conversion attempt, kept Scotland in control. The game ended with Scotland leading 18-3, maintaining their numerical superiority while Italy scored off a charged-down clearance. Scotland's lineup consisted of Paterson at fullback, Webster on the wing, and Craig as the starting hooker. Italy's lineup featured de Marigny as the fly-half, Bergamasco as the number eight, and Masi in the center.
